ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Beginning with 12th century troubadour poetry, we surveyed traditions of medieval song from France to England. Yes, I would recommend the course for medievalists and modernists alike.

This class has looked at lyrics from a wide variety of perspectives, from genre to performance and transmission. We looked at music and manuscripts, at plays and short poems. I would highly recommend this class because it has been so varied, and the work we have done has clearly been relevant to students from several periods and disciplines.

A survey of the "lyric" in the Medieval period in England and France, focusing on multi-dimensional aspects of the lyric (text, song, image, manuscript). A knowledge of Old French would be beneficial, though without it, the texts can be read in translation. I would recommend this course to another student! I learned more in this course about the value of questioning genre and preconceptions of literature than I ever considered beforehand. It was illuminating and downright fun!

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Good experience of speaking across period and discipline divides.

This course has taught me to challenge a lot of the assumptions that can be made regarding genre and regarding manuscript studies, which I hope will influence my thinking from now on. The texts themselves have been a pleasure to read and I was glad to have been introduced to them. I also think that the weekly blogging has given me experience in writing shorter responses.

To put it plainly, I had no idea that this aspect of Medieval studies even existed--I hadn't given it thought before. I absolutely loved every single bit of this course and the material and I am seriously considering many facets of this course in my future research and in my study of medieval literature. So much remains untapped in this incredible niche! I hope to do much more work on it in the future.
